importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Jan. 6, 2021 Capitol riot when Christopher Moynihan participated in the storming of the U.S. Capitol, which led to his initial criminal charges and subsequent pardon.
The date when Christopher Moynihan completed his sentence and was released under supervised release, marking a key point in his legal timeline before the pardon.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the Jan. 6, 2021 Capitol riot through 2025 reflects the broader national debate over the pardons issued by President Trump to participants in the riot, including repeat offenders and violent individuals, and the rising threat to public officials.

keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by President Trump after participating in the Jan. 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly sent text messages threatening to kill Jeffries, including messages such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
The arrest occurred after the FBI advised the New York State Police of the threats, and Moynihan was arraigned in Clinton, N.Y., with a bond set at $10,000 cash or $30,000 to $80,000 secured.

Moynihan was previously sentenced to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release in 2023, and received a full pardon as part of a broader blanket pardon of over 1,500 Capitol riot defendants.

House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries criticized the pardon, stating that many of the pardoned individuals have committed additional violent crimes since being released, including threats against lawmakers.
The incident reflects a growing concern over the safety of elected officials, with Capitol Police reporting 14,000 threat assessments in 2025, up from previous years.
This case raises broader questions about the ethics and effectiveness of blanket pardons for individuals involved in violent political acts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol riot participant pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021, has been arrested for allegedly sending threatening text messages to U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, stating he would 'kill him for the future' and 'must be eliminated.' The arrest, made by the New York State Police after FBI intelligence, follows Moynihan's prior 2023 conviction and 21-month prison sentence. The case highlights growing public concern over the safety of lawmakers and the controversial blanket pardons issued to riot participants, many of whom have committed further violent acts after release. This incident underscores a broader national debate about the consequences of executive pardons in cases involving political violence.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
